definition: to push oneself forward/to seek fame/to be in the limelight

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
point of a spear/edge of a tool/vanguard/forward (in sports team)
suffix for nouns
head/hair style/the top/end/beginning or end/a stub/remnant/chief/boss/side/aspect/first/leading/classifier for pigs or livestock/CL:個|个[ge4]

sentences.english: Mrs. Chen loves to steal the show at parties.
sentences.chinese: 陈太太喜欢在宴会中出锋头。

definition: to decide and act alone (idiom); to take arbitrary action/a law unto oneself
(coll.) to enjoy showing off
argumentative/quarrelsome
frank and outspoken (idiom)
flatterer
to think of oneself as high and pure (idiom); smug and self-righteous/holier-than-thou
lit. to argue who is right and wrong (idiom); to quibble/a storm in a teacup
to gossip and meddle/to shoot one's mouth off/talkative
see 心直口快[xin1 zhi2 kou3 kuai4]
to think too much of oneself/self-important/arrogant
to say not a word that is not appropriate (idiom)/wrongly used for 口不擇言|口不择言[kou3 bu4 ze2 yan2]
to choose what is good and hold fast to it (idiom)
to meddle/to be a "nosy Parker"/to be too inquisitive about other people's business
(dialect) hen/prostitute/(Tw) interfering/nosy/busybody (from Taiwanese 家婆, Tai-lo pr. [ke-pô])
(Tw) unreasonable/overbearing/with no regard for others
to like to look good in the eyes of others/sensitive about how one is regarded by others/proud
